article.headline: Arkansas 72, Winthrop 49
article.story: ST. THOMAS, U.S. Virgin Islands (AP) -- Eric Ferguson scored 16 points and Olu Famutimi 17 to lead Arkansas to a 72-49 victory over Winthrop in Friday's first round of the Paradise Jam tournament. The Razorbacks shot 65 percent from three-point range, hitting 11 of 17 long-distance shots, and outscored the Eagles by 20 in the second half after breaking away from a tie game. It was the second-best three-point percentage in school history. In 1999, Arkansas hit 14-of-21 (.667) against Western Carolina in a 90-54 victory in 1999. The Razorbacks play Sunday against Troy State. Ferguson, who played 22 minutes, also had four assists. Famutimi led Arkansas' rebounding with eight. Arkansas led 33-30 at halftime. But the game was tied at 40 points each with 16:38 left when the Razorbacks drew away with a 11-0 run. A free throw broke that streak, but Arkansas added another 7-0 run streak and led 58-41 with 8:26 to play. The Razorbacks' biggest lead was 70-46 with 3:48 remaining. Ronnie Brewer finished with 11 points for Arkansas. Craig Bradshaw led the Eagles with 12 while Martin finished with 11.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
